1454202154747678725.text: And the bill is paid for and will reduce the deficit by leveling the playing field to ensure the middle-class don’t continue paying a higher rate in taxes than billionaires and corporations.

1454202153137016834.text: With more than $500 billion, BBB will protect our planet & combat #ClimateChange. This investment in our planet’s future grows jobs by investing in the green economy and puts us on a path to meet our carbon goals by 2030 w/ USA-made tech.

1454202151849373700.text: BBB makes a transformative investment in children & caregiving for Georgia’s families through universal & free pre-K, affordable childcare, and a continuation of the enhanced #ChildTaxCut. It also delivers affordable, high-quality home care for seniors & disabled people.

1454202150209327106.text: BBB will dramatically lower health care costs for Americans. In addition to closing the coverage gap, it strengthens the #ACA, caps health insurance premiums at 8.5% of income, and enables Medicare to cover hearing benefits.

1454202148821032967.text: #BBB includes one of my top priorities: closing the Medicaid coverage gap for millions of Americans in non-expansion states like #Georgia! This provides new access to affordable health care for over 600,000 Georgians and 4 million people around the country.

1425175910349742085.text:
If the 30 day deadline passes, voters classified as “inactive” will still be able to vote, and doing so within the next two years will return your voting status to “active.” 
Those who don’t meet either of those deadlines will then be fully removed from the rolls.

1425175909406019588.text: If you receive a notice and want to maintain your active status, you will have 30 days to respond according to the postcard’s instructions before being characterized as “inactive.”

1425175908214792195.text:
Even if you haven’t moved recently, you still might receive a notice. 

Under the state’s “use it or lose it” law, voters who haven’t participated in elections or had contact with elections offices for 5+ years will be removed from voter rolls.

1425175907183075328.text: A large portion of these 185,000 individuals have likely moved, such as students who registered to vote while attending colleges in Georgia and have since moved away, but other removals are based on inactivity.

1410681237690368003.text: Even though #SB202 is law today, the fight continues to remove barriers to voting and to ensure fair elections.

1410681236528504835.text: Six sections of Georgia’s contentious election bill go into effect today, restricting absentee ballot voting by adding ID requirements and limiting drop boxes, banning line warming, and allowing the state to take over local boards of elections.

1410668317631823877.text: Wondering why I support a commission to review what happened on January 6th? Look no further: https://t.co/xn97VhgtgM

1410648665925079047.text: If you didn’t already believe that the right to vote was under attack, today confirms that our fight is just beginning. We must protect the right to vote. #ForThePeople #JohnLewisVotingRightsAct

1410648664280866820.text: If you are a registered voter, you deserve to have your voice heard. I am deeply disappointed in today’s partisan rulings that will undoubtedly pave the path for even more voting restriction laws in states disappointed with the results of recent elections.

1410648662930345986.text: In a separate ruling today, the Supreme Court decided in a California case that political donors have a "right" to anonymity. This decreases transparency in politics and allows a handful of wealthy Americans to disguise who’s really pulling the strings.

1410648659407028227.text: The ruling also sided with Arizona’s ban on ballot collecting, a useful resource in rural areas — including among Native populations — when polling places are harder to reach and mail service isn’t always consistent.

1410648658111086595.text: In Gwinnett County alone, there are over 150 voting precincts that are often subject to change between elections, causing voters to show up at the wrong location. Today’s SCOTUS ruling holds up an Arizona law declaring that votes cast in the wrong precinct can be tossed out.

1410631165346729987.text: Today I voted to pass the #INVESTAct, which includes four of my bills to #FutureFitTheSuburbs, and reimagines America’s transportation and #infrastructure while creating jobs for our communities. 1409980367570878465.text: It’s time to invest in #infrastructure that supports the suburbs, creates jobs, and addresses the threat of climate change.

1409980366593708034.text: In sprawling areas like the Atlanta suburbs, light rail isn’t always the best option to serve our needs. Under my legislation, flexible transit options like Express Lane Transit projects would be eligible for additional funding to increase transit in underserved areas.

1409980365570203655.text: The sun that beats down on our roads and right-of-ways is prime for harvesting energy. My Solar Use Network (SUN) Act makes common-sense changes so we can use “dead space” on our roads to install solar panels and generate clean energy.

1409980364546846724.text: Greenways connect parks and communities with bike and pedestrian trails providing recreation, promoting economic development, and providing recreational opportunities. My National and Regional Greenways Act would support the construction and expansion of these projects.

1409980363456364546.text: Water is one of our nation’s most vital resources and #GA07 is emerging as a center of innovation around water technology. My Wastewater Infrastructure Modernization Act helps public utilities invest in smart water technologies to lower costs and improve delivery of clean water.

1409980362361552898.text: As we build #infrastructure for the 21st century economy and prepare for the effects of climate change, I’m ensuring the suburbs are not left behind. FOUR of my #FutureFitTheSuburbs bills are included in the #INVESTAct coming to the floor this week:

1405577414177181703.text:
Minh’s dream for the future is that his daughter continues to thrive and that her children have access to a good education too. 

As for himself? “I look forward to retiring someday but I will stay in America. I like America.”

1405577412973375495.text: Immigrants come to our country seeking opportunity, but bring with them intelligence, creativity, innovation, and drive that makes our community stronger. It was an honor to meet Minh and share his #GA07ImmigrantStory.

1405577411547340800.text: In America, their daughter had the opportunity to receive a great public education, attend pharmacy school at the University of Georgia, and get her master’s degree — opportunities afforded to them through careful saving, a manufacturing career, and hard work.

1405577410356068356.text: Five years after arriving in America, Minh took the test to become a citizen, and upon receiving his certificate, immediately started the process of sponsoring his wife to join him in America where they could start a family.

1405577408955260928.text: With a background in chemistry, Minh spent time innovating and exploring how they could use recycled plastics in their products to become more environmentally responsible. He helped recruit other Vietnamese immigrants, trained them, and today is Plant Manager.

1405577407571107843.text: Shortly after arriving, Minh began working a manufacturing job at AutoVentshade, now @LundInter. Two weeks were set aside for training, but Minh quickly learned the ropes in just two days. He has now worked at the company for 37 years.

1405577406405042176.text: In August of 1983, Minh made the tough decision to leave behind his family, friends, and new wife to find a better life for them. Alone with only $5 in his pocket, he started his journey through Thailand and Singapore to learn American culture, and was then sent to Atlanta.

1405577405176111109.text: Minh went on to earn a master’s degree in chemistry, and met his wife at the school where they both worked, but quickly realized that $10/month was not going to be enough to raise a family.

1405577403909484551.text: Minh grew up in Vietnam where he excelled academically, and was chosen from a highly selective process to attend college and study chemistry. After attaining his bachelor’s degree, he became a high school teacher in South Vietnam, earning $10 per month.

1392553159428481024.text: Yesterday, @SenateRules held a markup on the #ForThePeopleAct, the important voting rights legislation that will secure access to the ballot. The House passed this bill months ago, and this is a crucial step in moving forward to make this the law of the land.

1392498714216910851.text: Creating a National Infrastructure Bank: This project would provide federal seed money to leverage significant private sector investment in major infrastructure projects that follow environmental guidelines.

1392498713160044545.text: An initiative to Upcycle Abandoned Malls: As more and more shopping goes online, retail malls — and the large plots of land they sit on — are going unoccupied and unused, taking up valuable real estate. These areas can be redeveloped in a way that serves the community.

1392498712350494722.text: The Building Up the Suburbs (BUS) Act: The BUS Act would fund a regional bus rapid transit system that would run along our major highways — or express lane transit — to help people get from suburban hubs to major commercial hubs while skipping the traffic.

1392498711322890241.text: The National & Regional Greenways Act: This legislation would provide funding for major bike and pedestrian paths that link parks and community centers, supporting projects like the visionary Chattahoochee River Greenway.

1360698058615500800.text: We will continue to resist the former president and his conspiracy theorist supporters at the ballot box, and there will be on-going legal action at the state and federal level. I look forward to seeing where that takes us.

1360698057764069383.text: Inciting a violent mob to attack the US Capitol to try to 'stiffen the spine' of the Vice President and Members of Congress to overturn the results of a free and fair election is not okay. Justice was not served today. But I will never give up on our democracy.

1360698056908410880.text: I remain firm in the belief that lying about the results of an election and trying to pressure officials into overturning the results of a free and fair election is not okay.

1360698056082149381.text: The result of former President Trump’s impeachment trial is disappointing, but not surprising. We remain deeply divided as a country about appropriate behavior for a president.

1359275309317644293.text: Our democracy requires people of good faith and ethics in order to make it work. Today, I ask the United States Senate to hear the evidence, to put the country before their political party, and to uphold their oath to defend our Constitution.

1359275307845443588.text: Actions have consequences, and on January 6th, we saw the impact of the former president’s words, first-hand. At such a fragile moment for our country, where the very foundation of our democracy is at stake, we must have accountability.

1359275306725613568.text: When I was sworn in as your congresswoman, I took an oath to support and defend the Constitution of the United States against all enemies, foreign and domestic. The Senators who will try the former President today took the same oath. Our words matter.

1359275305714778115.text: Trying to undermine that result, just one month ago, former president Trump used the lie that our election was fraudulent to incite a violent mob to attack the US Capitol.

1359275304603316224.text: Despite three recounts and a number of investigations, the results of the 2020 election remain clear: Joe Biden won Georgia.
